evidence_items.text: The gliders were competing in an inter-club event at Hinton-in-the-Hedges Airfield. The competition involved navigating a fixed course task with designated turn points. Pilots were grouped into three categories: Novice, Intermediate, and Pundit. The pilot of G-DJMD competed in the Intermediate Class, tasked with a 156 km course, while the pilot of G-DCTB was in the Novice Class, assigned a shorter route of 118 km. The primary distinction between classes was the course length.

Relative positions of G-DJMD and G-DCTB as they positioned to join downwind At approximately the same time, the pilot of the parachute drop aircraft, having despatched his jumpers 3, positioned to join the circuit on right base for Runway (hard). When descending through 800 ft on final, he observed a glider on a “tight left base” for Runway 06 just below his level. He transmitted on the Hinton Radio frequency, “glider, are you going in ahead of me?”, receiving the response, “I’m number one”. The pilot acknowledged the radio call and initiated a turn to the left to position behind the glider. As he turned, he saw another glider, that appeared to be aligned with Runway 09, slightly behind but level with the first.

A witness near the threshold of Runway (grass) observed two gliders approaching the airfield and was able to identify them by type. G-DJMD was lined up with Runway (grass) and G-DCTB was slightly lower and ahead on a shallower approach profile, apparently lined up with Runway (hard). As they approached the airfield boundary, G-DCTB made a “shallow right turn” towards Runway (grass), which was occupied with three gliders waiting to launch. G-DCTB’s airbrakes were observed to be closed or partially closed. The manoeuvre placed G-DCTB on a conflicting path with G-DJMD.

The gliders collided at approximately 20 to 30 ft above the intersection of Runway (hard) and the disused Runway 09 threshold. On collision, G-DJMD pitched up rapidly then rolled right until inverted before striking the ground in an inverted attitude. G-DCTB came to rest upright but entangled with G-DJMD.

Another witness at the north-west of the airfield, some 250 m distant, observed an approaching glider lined up with Runway (grass) with its airbrakes open, and another glider lined up with Runway 09 at an offset of approximately 30°. They converged and collided approximately 30 ft above the ground. One glider pitched up, rolled inverted, then pitched down, its canopy detaching before impact with the ground4.
Competitors and officials provided immediate assistance, followed promptly by emergency services. The pilot of G-DJMD suffered fatal injuries, while the pilot of G-DCTB sustained serious injuries.

Accident site Both gliders struck the ground at the western end of disused Runway 09. G-DCTB came to rest upright, facing across the runway to the right. G-DJMD came to rest inverted, with its nose close to the tail of G-DCTB, and its left wing leading edge lodged underneath the airbrake cover of G-DCTB’s right wing.

A debris field of approximately 70 m preceded the gliders, beginning near the intersection of Runway 06 and disused concrete Runway 09. The debris comprised pieces of canopy transparency, instrument panel coaming, wingtip, aircraft skin, and personal effects.

Other avionics G-DJMD was also fitted with a Kanardia EMSIS, an instrument used to provide the pilot with an artificial horizon, speed and heading information. This unit was disassembled, as it records flight data including aircraft track and orientation, and several flights worth of data were successfully retrieved from its onboard non-volatile memory. However, the accident flight was not recovered. The manufacturer commented that a firmware update, to fix a known issue with correctly recording the GPS date, had not been applied and that some of the memory space reserved for recordings appeared corrupted; this may have affected the recording of the accident flight.

Aircraft information G-DJMD: Schempp-Hirth Discus B The Discus B is a single-seat glider constructed from carbon fibre and fibreglass. It has a 15.0 m wingspan, upturned wingtips, and a T-tail with fixed horizontal stabiliser and elevator.
Flying controls are operated by a central control stick and rudder pedals. The glider is equipped with a retractable, single-wheel main landing gear, fixed tailwheel, and airbrakes.
In G-DJMD the pilot was secured by a five-point harness and wore a parachute. There was an additional foam cushion located underneath the seat.
G-DJMD was manufactured in 1988, had 2,254 hours at its last inspection, and held a valid Airworthiness Review Certificate (ARC). Its paintwork was white and it displayed the competition number P23.

G-DCTB was manufactured in 1972, had 3,128 hours at its last inspection, and held a valid ARC. It had red paintwork on the nose cone, wing tips, and the bottom and top of the rudder. G-DCTB displayed the competition number 579.
An upper section of composite instrument panel coaming was found approximately 45 m prior to the fuselage, and the instrument panel was found adjacent to the glider.

The canopy transparency had fractured into many pieces, which were found scattered the length of the debris field. The canopy’s frame had broken in three places; at both front bend points and at the top of the rear ‘hoop’. The frame pieces were found next to the fuselage.

Tail The tail section was intact but had been abraded from contact with the runway surface when inverted. The rudder pedal controls were connected to the rudder via cables and control tubes, and there was control system continuity between the control stick and elevators. All control surfaces moved freely.

Wings The left wing’s leading edge at its mid-span position was wedged underneath the air brake cover on G-DCTB’s right wing upper surface. Both wings were intact and had abrasion damage from contact with the runway surface. The right wing leading edge had a contact damage point; from which the leading edge had split along its length.

Control system continuity was established between the control stick and the ailerons. The air brake lever could be rotated and moved fore and aft, but this did not move the air brakes which were in the deployed position.

G-DCTB Fuselage and Canopy G-DCTB came to rest upright. The tip of the nose had impact damage and the fuselage frame behind the cockpit was distorted and cracked in a manner suggesting it was subject to a hard upward force upon landing. The main gear wheel was found in the retracted position, likely from the landing force. The sides of the cockpit area had also split from the landing force. The seat had come away from some of its mounting points but was intact.
The canopy frame was broken, and the canopy transparency had fractured. The majority of the canopy pieces were found in the immediate vicinity of the fuselage.

The controls for the all-moving tailplane were intact and free to move from the control stick to the break in the tail and were connected to the tailplane past the break. The tip of the left tailplane was missing and was in the preceding debris field approximately 8.5 m from the fuselage.
Wings The right wingtip had impact damage; a section of the underside wingtip skin had become detached and was found approximately 40 m further back in the debris field.
G-DCTB right wingtip damage, and underside wingtip skin section The right wing’s leading edge was covered with heavy black marking, that extended to both upper and lower surfaces.

Survivability Both pilots wore parachutes; there is no regulation covering the use of emergency parachutes although there is a BGA Operational Regulation that requires glider occupants to carry emergency parachutes when flying in cloud and their use is considered a reasonable precaution. The proximity of the gliders to the ground when they collided would have precluded safe and effective use of a parachute in this situation.

The investigation made the following findings: ● When an aeronautical radio station is licensed and approved to provide an Air Ground Communication Service, the service must be provided inside published hours of operation, unless promulgated otherwise by NOTAM or other suitable means.
● The British Gliding Association (BGA) to promulgate information on the avoidance of midair collisions.
● The respective gliding clubs to clarify their requirements for the use of radios by pilots.

slot_statements.availability: The communication/coordination breakdown among crew was evident and documented in the early phase of the historical timeline for Discus_B_G-DJMD_Standard_Cirrus_G-DCTB_12-25.
slot_statements.defeater_resistance: The explanation of communication/coordination breakdown among crew is resistant to defeaters, as alternative causes have been ruled out based on the evidence from the early historical timeline of Discus_B_G-DJMD_Standard_Cirrus_G-DCTB_12-25.
slot_statements.fit_to_key_features: The communication/coordination breakdown among crew aligns with the key features observed in the early historical data of Discus_B_G-DJMD_Standard_Cirrus_G-DCTB_12-25, including misaligned actions and unclear information exchange.

node.statement: The communication/coordination breakdown among crew was evident and documented in the early phase of the historical timeline for Discus_B_G-DJMD_Standard_Cirrus_G-DCTB_12-25.

assumptions: The observed conflicting flight paths and radio exchanges imply communication/coordination breakdown among crew.
defeaters: Direct documentation or explicit statements of communication breakdown among crew in early timeline
Evidence showing effective communication and coordination among crew

quotes.exact_quote: At approximately the same time, the pilot of the parachute drop aircraft... transmitted on the Hinton Radio frequency, 'glider, are you going in ahead of me?', receiving the response, 'I'm number one'. The pilot acknowledged the radio call and initiated a turn to the left to position behind the glider. As he turned, he saw another glider... slightly behind but level with the first.

A witness near the threshold of Runway (grass) observed two gliders approaching the airfield... G-DCTB made a 'shallow right turn' towards Runway (grass), which was occupied with three gliders waiting to launch. The manoeuvre placed G-DCTB on a conflicting path with G-DJMD.

outcome.reasoning_summary: The evidence (H2, H3) describes radio communication and observed flight paths that indicate coordination attempts and conflicting maneuvers, implying communication/coordination breakdown among crew early in the timeline.
outcome.uncertainty_source: No explicit documentation or direct statements confirming communication/coordination breakdown; evidence is observational and inferential.

node.statement: The communication/coordination breakdown among crew aligns with the key features observed in the early historical data of Discus_B_G-DJMD_Standard_Cirrus_G-DCTB_12-25, including misaligned actions and unclear information exchange.

assumptions: The described maneuvers and radio communications reflect the crew's coordination and communication status
defeaters: Additional evidence showing clear, effective communication and coordination among crew
Data indicating no misalignment or unclear information exchange in early historical data

quotes.exact_quote: At approximately the same time, the pilot of the parachute drop aircraft... transmitted on the Hinton Radio frequency, 'glider, are you going in ahead of me?' receiving the response, 'I'm number one'. The pilot acknowledged the radio call and initiated a turn to the left to position behind the glider. As he turned, he saw another glider... slightly behind but level with the first.

G-DJMD was lined up with Runway (grass) and G-DCTB was slightly lower and ahead on a shallower approach profile... G-DCTB made a 'shallow right turn' towards Runway (grass), which was occupied with three gliders waiting to launch. The manoeuvre placed G-DCTB on a conflicting path with G-DJMD.

A witness... observed an approaching glider lined up with Runway (grass) with its airbrakes open, and another glider lined up with Runway 09 at an offset of approximately 30°. They converged and collided approximately 30 ft above the ground.

outcome.reasoning_summary: Evidence H2, H3, and H5 directly describe the positioning and maneuvers of the gliders leading to a collision, indicating misaligned actions and unclear information exchange consistent with communication/coordination breakdown.
outcome.uncertainty_source: Ambiguity in the extent to which communication failures versus pilot decisions contributed to the breakdown

slot_statements.availability: The environmental or marking deficiency is present and observable within the scope of Discus_B_G-DJMD_Standard_Cirrus_G-DCTB_12-25:hist_t1_early.
slot_statements.defeater_resistance: The identification of the environmental or marking deficiency is robust and resistant to defeaters within the context of Discus_B_G-DJMD_Standard_Cirrus_G-DCTB_12-25:hist_t1_early.
slot_statements.fit_to_key_features: The environmental or marking deficiency aligns with the key features defined for Discus_B_G-DJMD_Standard_Cirrus_G-DCTB_12-25:hist_t1_early.

node.statement: The environmental or marking deficiency is present and observable within the scope of Discus_B_G-DJMD_Standard_Cirrus_G-DCTB_12-25:hist_t1_early.

defeaters: Evidence showing specific environmental or marking deficiencies present and observable during the event.
outcome.reasoning_summary: No evidence in the provided history or synopsis items indicates the presence or observability of an environmental or marking deficiency within the scope of the specified gliders and time.

slot_statements.availability: Mechanical/control failure is present in the scope Discus_B_G-DJMD_Standard_Cirrus_G-DCTB_12-25:hist_t1_early.
slot_statements.defeater_resistance: Mechanical/control failure is resistant to defeaters within the scope Discus_B_G-DJMD_Standard_Cirrus_G-DCTB_12-25:hist_t1_early.
slot_statements.fit_to_key_features: Mechanical/control failure fits the key features observed in Discus_B_G-DJMD_Standard_Cirrus_G-DCTB_12-25:hist_t1_early.

node.statement: Mechanical/control failure is present in the scope Discus_B_G-DJMD_Standard_Cirrus_G-DCTB_12-25:hist_t1_early.

defeaters: Discovery of explicit evidence of mechanical or control failure in the gliders during the event.
outcome.reasoning_summary: No evidence in the provided history or synopsis indicates the presence of mechanical or control failure in the gliders G-DJMD or G-DCTB during the event.

slot_statements.availability: The procedural deviation in pushback execution is documented and accessible within the Discu_B_G-DJMD_Standard_Cirrus_G-DCTB_12-25:hist_t1_early scope.
slot_statements.defeater_resistance: The identification of procedural deviation in pushback execution withstands potential counterarguments and alternative explanations within the Discu_B_G-DJMD_Standard_Cirrus_G-DCTB_12-25:hist_t1_early scope.
slot_statements.fit_to_key_features: The procedural deviation in pushback execution aligns with the key features and criteria defined for pushback procedures in the Discu_B_G-DJMD_Standard_Cirrus_G-DCTB_12-25:hist_t1_early context.

node.statement: The procedural deviation in pushback execution is documented and accessible within the Discu_B_G-DJMD_Standard_Cirrus_G-DCTB_12-25:hist_t1_early scope.

defeaters: Evidence showing documentation of the procedural deviation within the specified scope
Explicit references to procedural deviation records in the Discu_B_G-DJMD_Standard_Cirrus_G-DCTB_12-25:hist_t1_early scope
outcome.reasoning_summary: No evidence in the provided items indicates that the procedural deviation in pushback execution is documented and accessible within the specified scope.

node.statement: The explanation of communication/coordination breakdown among crew is resistant to defeaters, as alternative causes have been ruled out based on the evidence from the early historical timeline of Discus_B_G-DJMD_Standard_Cirrus_G-DCTB_12-25.

assumptions: That the witness observations are accurate and comprehensive
That no other unreported factors contributed to the breakdown
defeaters: If evidence of mechanical failure, environmental factors, or pilot incapacitation were found
If radio communication logs showed misunderstandings or failures not accounted for
If witness statements contradicted the observed sequence of events

quotes.exact_quote: Relative positions of G-DJMD and G-DCTB as they positioned to join downwind At approximately the same time, the pilot of the parachute drop aircraft, having despatched his jumpers 3, positioned to join the circuit on right base for Runway (hard). When descending through 800 ft on final, he observed a glider on a “tight left base” for Runway 06 just below his level. He transmitted on the Hinton Radio frequency, “glider, are you going in ahead of me?”, receiving the response, “I’m number one”. The pilot acknowledged the radio call and initiated a turn to the left to position behind the glider. As he turned, he saw another glider, that appeared to be aligned with Runway 09, slightly behind but level with the first.

A witness near the threshold of Runway (grass) observed two gliders approaching the airfield and was able to identify them by type. G-DJMD was lined up with Runway (grass) and G-DCTB was slightly lower and ahead on a shallower approach profile, apparently lined up with Runway (hard). As they approached the airfield boundary, G-DCTB made a “shallow right turn” towards Runway (grass), which was occupied with three gliders waiting to launch. G-DCTB’s airbrakes were observed to be closed or partially closed. The manoeuvre placed G-DCTB on a conflicting path with G-DJMD.

Another witness at the north-west of the airfield, some 250 m distant, observed an approaching glider lined up with Runway (grass) with its airbrakes open, and another glider lined up with Runway 09 at an offset of approximately 30°. They converged and collided approximately 30 ft above the ground. One glider pitched up, rolled inverted, then pitched down, its canopy detaching before impact with the ground4.

outcome.reasoning_summary: The historical evidence (H2, H3, H5) provides detailed observations of the gliders' relative positions, maneuvers, and the collision sequence, supporting that communication and coordination breakdown occurred. The evidence shows no alternative causes such as mechanical failure or environmental factors, indicating that alternative causes have been ruled out.
outcome.uncertainty_source: lack of direct recordings of the accident flight and incomplete flight data from G-DJMD's Kanardia EMSIS (H9) limits full reconstruction of communication events

children_spec.statement: Relevant environmental information was not available to the pilot at the time of the incident
children_spec.test_procedure: Check if weather reports, NOTAMs, or other environmental data were accessible to the pilot before and during the flight

children_spec.statement: Markings or signage necessary for safe operation were missing or not present at the location
children_spec.test_procedure: Inspect the physical environment for presence or absence of required markings or signage at the time of the incident

children_spec.statement: Available environmental or marking information was not updated or was outdated
children_spec.test_procedure: Verify the currency and accuracy of environmental data and markings against official records and updates

node.statement: Available environmental or marking information was not updated or was outdated

defeaters: Evidence showing outdated or not updated environmental or marking information would change the assessment.
outcome.reasoning_summary: No evidence in the provided items indicates that available environmental or marking information was not updated or was outdated.

children_spec.statement: Mechanical control components are physically present in the system
children_spec.test_procedure: Inspect the system to verify the presence of all mechanical control components

children_spec.statement: Mechanical control components are accessible and not obstructed
children_spec.test_procedure: Check for any physical obstructions or inaccessibility of mechanical control components

children_spec.statement: Mechanical control components are in operational condition and not failed
children_spec.test_procedure: Perform functional tests to confirm mechanical control components operate as intended

node.statement: Mechanical control components are physically present in the system

defeaters: If evidence showed missing or destroyed mechanical control components
If control system continuity was broken or components were absent

quotes.exact_quote: The Discus B is a single-seat glider constructed from carbon fibre and fibreglass. It has a 15.0 m wingspan, upturned wingtips, and a T-tail with fixed horizontal stabiliser and elevator.
Flying controls are operated by a central control stick and rudder pedals. The glider is equipped with a retractable, single-wheel main landing gear, fixed tailwheel, and airbrakes.

Tail The tail section was intact but had been abraded from contact with the runway surface when inverted. The rudder pedal controls were connected to the rudder via cables and control tubes, and there was control system continuity between the control stick and elevators. All control surfaces moved freely.

Control system continuity was established between the control stick and the ailerons. The air brake lever could be rotated and moved fore and aft, but this did not move the air brakes which were in the deployed position.
The controls for the all-moving tailplane were intact and free to move from the control stick to the break in the tail and were connected to the tailplane past the break.

outcome.reasoning_summary: Evidence H10, H11, H17, H19, and H22 directly describe the presence and physical integrity of mechanical control components in the gliders, confirming they are physically present in the system.

node.statement: Mechanical control components are accessible and not obstructed

defeaters: Direct evidence of mechanical control components being physically obstructed or inaccessible
Evidence of mechanical failure or obstruction in control components

quotes.exact_quote: The rudder pedal controls were connected to the rudder via cables and control tubes, and there was control system continuity between the control stick and elevators. All control surfaces moved freely.

Control system continuity was established between the control stick and the ailerons. The air brake lever could be rotated and moved fore and aft, but this did not move the air brakes which were in the deployed position.

outcome.reasoning_summary: Evidence H17 and H19 indicate that control system continuity was established and control surfaces moved freely, suggesting mechanical control components were accessible and not obstructed. However, the air brakes were found deployed and did not move with the lever, which may indicate some issue but not necessarily obstruction or inaccessibility.
outcome.uncertainty_source: No explicit statement or direct inspection report confirming accessibility or absence of obstruction of mechanical control components.

children_spec.statement: Pushback procedure documentation is accessible to the crew during operation
children_spec.test_procedure: Check if the pushback procedure manuals or quick reference guides are physically or digitally available in the cockpit at the time of pushback

children_spec.statement: Pushback equipment and resources required by the procedure are available and operational
children_spec.test_procedure: Verify the presence and functionality of pushback tugs, communication devices, and other necessary equipment during the pushback phase

children_spec.statement: Qualified personnel required to execute the pushback procedure are present and available
children_spec.test_procedure: Confirm that trained ground crew and flight crew members are present and ready to perform the pushback according to procedure

node.statement: Pushback equipment and resources required by the procedure are available and operational

defeaters: Evidence indicating availability and operational status of pushback equipment and resources as required by the procedure.
outcome.reasoning_summary: No evidence in the provided history or synopsis mentions pushback equipment or resources availability or operational status.

children_spec.statement: Crew members were physically present and accessible during critical communication periods
children_spec.test_procedure: Check crew attendance logs and communication timestamps to verify presence and accessibility

children_spec.statement: Communication devices and systems were operational and available for use by the crew
children_spec.test_procedure: Inspect maintenance records and system logs to confirm device functionality during the event

children_spec.statement: Crew had sufficient time and opportunity to communicate effectively during the operation
children_spec.test_procedure: Analyze timeline of events and communication exchanges to assess time availability for coordination

node.statement: Crew members were physically present and accessible during critical communication periods

defeaters: Direct statements or evidence confirming crew physical presence and accessibility during critical communication periods
Evidence of radio or other communication logs showing crew availability

When descending through 800 ft on final, he observed a glider on a “tight left base” for Runway 06 just below his level. He transmitted on the Hinton Radio frequency, “glider, are you going in ahead of me?”, receiving the response, “I’m number one”. The pilot acknowledged the radio call and initiated a turn to the left to position behind the glider. As he turned, he saw another glider, that appeared to be aligned with Runway 09, slightly behind but level with the first.

A witness near the threshold of Runway (grass) observed two gliders approaching the airfield and was able to identify them by type. G-DJMD was lined up with Runway (grass) and G-DCTB was slightly lower and ahead on a shallower approach profile, apparently lined up with Runway (hard). As they approached the airfield boundary, G-DCTB made a “shallow right turn” towards Runway (grass), which was occupied with three gliders waiting to launch. outcome.reasoning_summary: Evidence H2 and H3 describe the positions and movements of the gliders and radio communication with other aircraft, but do not explicitly confirm that crew members were physically present and accessible during critical communication periods.
outcome.uncertainty_source: absence of explicit evidence about crew physical presence and accessibility during critical communication periods

node.statement: Relevant environmental information was not available to the pilot at the time of the incident

defeaters: Evidence that the pilot lacked critical environmental information such as runway alignment, traffic position, or radio communication at the time of the incident.

quotes.exact_quote: At approximately the same time, the pilot of the parachute drop aircraft, having despatched his jumpers 3, positioned to join the circuit on right base for Runway (hard). When descending through 800 ft on final, he observed a glider on a “tight left base” for Runway 06 just below his level. He transmitted on the Hinton Radio frequency, “glider, are you going in ahead of me?”, receiving the response, “I’m number one”. The pilot acknowledged the radio call and initiated a turn to the left to position behind the glider. As he turned, he saw another glider, that appeared to be aligned with Runway 09, slightly behind but level with the first.

A witness near the threshold of Runway (grass) observed two gliders approaching the airfield and was able to identify them by type. G-DJMD was lined up with Runway (grass) and G-DCTB was slightly lower and ahead on a shallower approach profile, apparently lined up with Runway (hard). As they approached the airfield boundary, G-DCTB made a “shallow right turn” towards Runway (grass), which was occupied with three gliders waiting to launch. G-DCTB’s airbrakes were observed to be closed or partially closed. The manoeuvre placed G-DCTB on a conflicting path with G-DJMD.

outcome.reasoning_summary: The evidence shows that pilots had visual and radio communication and were aware of other gliders' positions (H2, H3), indicating relevant environmental information was available to the pilot at the time of the incident. There is no direct evidence that relevant environmental information was unavailable.
outcome.uncertainty_source: No explicit statements about unavailability of environmental information; ambiguity in pilot situational awareness.
